questions.text: Which of the following is a subunit vaccine?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B vaccine is an example of a subunit vaccine made using HBsAg.

Subunit vaccines are produced from macromolecules derived from immunogenic components of organisms by recombinant DNA technology. E.g., HPV vaccine (uses L1 major capsid protein) and hepatitis B vaccine (uses HBsAg). 

BCG is a live attenuated vaccine, IPV is an inactivated vaccine and DPT has diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and a killed pertussis component.

questions.text: In 2020, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved Inmazeb , a mixture of three monoclonal antibodies, as the first FDA-approved treatment for which of the following deadly diseases?
questions.solution:
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved Inmazeb (atoltivimab, maftivimab, and odesivimab), a mixture of three monoclonal antibodies, as the first FDA-approved treatment for Zaire ebolavirus (Ebola virus) infection in adult and pediatric patients.

It is indicated for the treatment of infection caused by Zaire ebolavirus in adult and pediatric patients, including neonates born to a mother who is RT-PCR positive for Zaire ebolavirus infection.

Inmazeb targets the glycoprotein that is on the surface of the Ebola virus. Glycoprotein attaches to the cell receptor and fuses the viral and host cell membranes allowing the virus to enter the cell. The three antibodies that makeup Inmazeb can bind to this glycoprotein simultaneously and block attachment and entry of the virus

Note: Patients who receive Inmazeb should avoid the concurrent administration of a live vaccine due to the treatment’s potential to inhibit replication of a live vaccine virus indicated for the prevention of Ebola virus infection and possibly reduce the vaccine’s efficacy.

Ebola virus is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa. It belongs to the Filoviridae family.

Fruit bats act as reservoir hosts of the virus and it is transmitted to humans only accidentally. Human-to-human transmission is through direct contact with blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.

The incubation period of the disease is 2 to 21 days. Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. The current treatment is mainly supportive. Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after a complete cure.

 

The electron micrograph image shows the Ebola virus.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine is most sensitive to heat?
questions.solution:
Oral Polio Vaccine is the most heat-sensitive vaccine. Hence, it is kept in the lower zone of the Ice Lined Refrigerator.

Vaccine sensitivity to freezing:

Rotavirus(liquid)< T,DT,dT< IPV < Hib(liquid)< HepB < Pentavalent <DTaP

Vaccines not damaged by freezing:

  • Yellow fever
  • BCG
  • Hib
  • Japanese encephalitis(live and inactivated)
  • Measles, mumps, rubella
  • OPV
  • Rabies
  • Rotavirus(Freeze-dried)
  • Varicella zoster

questions.text: You should perform a shake test prior to using all of the following vaccines, except ________.
questions.solution:
Only the injectable polio vaccine (IPV) is freeze sensitive, not the oral polio vaccine (OPV). Hence, a shake test is not relevant for OPV.

The shake test is done to check for damage to vaccines that are sensitive to freezing temperatures.

Steps to perform the shake test:

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial, and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing, and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze sensitive:

  • Hep B
  • Pentavalent
  • IPV
  • DPT 
  • TT
  • PCV

Vaccines like OPV and rotavirus vaccines do not lose their potency and efficacy on freezing. Hence, these vaccines can be used again once they liquefy.

questions.text: A child has come to you for the administration of the IPV vaccine, as part of his routine immunisation schedule. Which of the following antibiotics may be found in this vaccine?
questions.solution:
IPV may contain trace amounts of streptomycin, neomycin or polymyxin B. 

MMR contain small amount of neomycin. 

Antibiotics are used during vaccine manufacture to prevent bacterial contamination of tissue culture cells.

questions.text:
A 20-day-old child who was not vaccinated at birth was brought to the OPD for vaccination. Which of the following vaccines can be administered to this child?
  1. BCG
  2. OPV-0
  3. HEP-B
questions.solution:
The vaccine that can be administered to a 20-day-old child who was not vaccinated at birth is BCG.

The vaccines that are administered at birth are BCG, OPV-0, HEP-B

  • BCG can be administered till 1 year of age
  • OPV-0 should be administered within 15 days after birth
  • HEP-B should be administered within 24 hours after birth

questions.text: A 20-year old female patient presented with painless lesions on the vulva as shown in the image below. Which of the following vaccines is not protective against this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition in the image is condyloma acuminata (venereal warts) caused by infection with human papilloma virus 6 or 11. The Cervarix vaccine does not protect against it. Cervarix offers protection against HPV subtypes 16,18, which cause CIN and Ca cervix.

The image shows multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal, as seen in condyloma acuminata. The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. They may be asymptomatic but can also cause discomfort, discharge, or bleeding. Treatment may include ablation, excision, or topical agents such as podophyllin and imiquimod.

The available vaccinations against HPV are summarized below.

Brand name Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil-9
Characteristic and HPV subtypes Bivalent:16,18 Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18 Nonavalent: 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58
Protects against: CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, CA cervix,  Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia, Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia
Dose 0.5ml  0.5ml 0.5ml
Administration 0, 1, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6months, i.m
Administered gender Female and male Female and male Female and male
Ideal Age range: 11-12 years,9-26 years  11-12 years, 9-26 years for both male and female

Females:11-12 years, 9-26 years

Males:11-12 years

9-15 years - FDA approved

Gardasil 9 has received expanded indication, which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers caused by HPV types 16,18,31,33,45,52,58.

questions.text: During a measles epidemic in the community, a 6-month-old child is brought to the vaccination camp. What would you do?

choices.text: Proceed with the immunization of the child for measles
Give half of the dose of usual vaccination
No vaccination is given as the child is less than 9 months
Give the vaccine only if the child develops symptoms

questions.solution:
In the setting of a measles epidemic, we proceed with immunization of measles for this child.

The scheduled age for receiving the first dose of measles vaccine is at 9 months. The second dose is given between 15 - 18 months of age such that the minimum interval between the 2 doses is 4 weeks.  A supplementary dose can be given at the age of  6 months for the following cases:

  • As a part of intensified service delivery during a measles outbreak 
  • In places where the risk of measles among infants < 9 months of age remains high (endemic countries experiencing regular outbreaks)
  • Individual infants at high risk of contracting measles (history of contact with known cases)
  • Infants traveling to countries experiencing measles outbreaks
  • Infants who are known to be HIV-infected or exposed 

Infants immunized between 6 months should further receive doses 1 and 2 according to the national schedule. Thus in the given case, this infant will be immunized at 6 months due to the epidemic and then receive the regular doses at 9 and 15-18 months of age.

questions.text:
Given below is a list of equipment used for the cold storage of vaccines. Arrange the cold storage equipment in the correct order of usage, starting from the primary health center level to the national level.
  1. Walk-in-Freezers
  2. Walk-in-coolers
  3. Deep freezer
  4. Ice lined refrigerators
questions.solution:
The cold chain equipments that are used at various healthcare strata starting from the primary health center to the national level are 4-3-2-1 i.e. ice lined refrigerators → deep freezer → walk-in-coolers → walk-in-freezers.

Ice-lined refrigerators (ILRs) are similar to conventional refrigerators and are lined with ice packs or tubes. They are categorized based on the vaccine storage capacity. Smaller ones are supplied to the primary health center (PHC) headquarters, while larger ones are supplied to district headquarters. They maintain a temperature of 2-8° Celsius for the storage of vaccines. They have different temperature zones for different vaccines and they are stored accordingly in the baskets that are provided in most ILRs.

Deep freezer (DF) is also similar to a conventional refrigerator but has a top-opening lid. It maintains a temperature of -15° to -25° celsius. It is used at the district level and above for the storage of oral polio vaccines for 3 months. At the sub-district level, it is used for freezing icepacks.

Walk-in-coolers (WIC) are insulated cold rooms with two cooling units with an uninterrupted power supply. They maintain a temperature of 2-8° celsius. They are used at government medical store depots, state, regional, and occasionally district level vaccine stores. 

Walk-in-freezers (WIF) are similar to WIC but maintain a temperature of -15° to -25° celsius. They are used at national, state, and regional vaccine stores.

Related Pearl: Cold Chain Equipment

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about the information obtained from the vaccine vial monitor 14 (VVM14) shown in the image below.

choices.text: It takes 14 days for the inner square to become darker than outer circle
It takes 14 days for the inner square and outer circle to reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the inner square and outer circle reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the outer circle color  becomes darker

questions.solution:
The correct statement is option 2.

The given scenario mentions VVM 14 (vaccine vial monitor 14), where 14 indicates the VVM number. It is the time in days for the inner square to reach the color of the outer circle when the vial is exposed to a constant temperature of 37°C. This color change signifies the discard point of the vial.

Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators that are routinely used to monitor vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain. It records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

There are currently 4 types of VVMs, they are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccines based on the VVM number. 

  • VVM 30: High Stability
  • VVM 14: Medium Stability
  • VVM 7: Moderate Stability
  • VVM 2: Least Stable

If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to high temperatures and should be discarded.

Purpose of VVMs:

  • Ensures that vaccines damaged by heat are not administered
  • Decision on which vaccines to be kept after a cold chain break occurs, minimizing unnecessary vaccine wastage
  • Decision on which vaccine is to be used first. Vaccines showing significant heat exposure should be used before those that show lower heat exposure, even if their expiry date is longer

There are two different locations for VVMs :

  • On the label of the vaccine: The vaccine vial, once opened, can be kept for subsequent immunization sessions for up to 28 days, regardless of the formulation of the product
  • In a location other than on the label (e.g., cap or neck of ampoule): The vaccine vial, once opened should be discarded at the end of the immunization session or within six hours of opening, whichever comes first, regardless of the formulation of the product

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A 7-week-old child presented with abdominal pain and red currant jelly stools. The mother gives a history of vaccination to the child 1 week prior. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. Which of the following vaccine is likely to be responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of abdominal pain, red currant jelly stool along with barium enema showing the claw sign is suggestive of intussusception. The mother gives a history of vaccination at 6 weeks of age and the Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a risk of developing intussusception, usually within a week after the first or second dose.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a very minimal risk of intussusception. An area of enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch acts as a lead point for intussusception.

Some lead points in children are Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts. Patients present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, vomiting, and passage of red currant jelly stools. Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the target sign/bull's eye sign (shown below) and pseudo kidney sign (seen longitudinally).

Barium enema shows a typical claw sign (shown below). This appearance is due to the barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space.

Treatment of intussusception includes hydrostatic reduction by enema using contrast material or air. Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences after hydrostatic reduction.

questions.text:
Open vial policy is applicable for which of the following vaccines?
  1. BCG
  2. DPT vaccine
  3. Oral Polio vaccine
  4. MR vaccine
  5. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
questions.solution:
Among the given vaccines open vial policy is applicable for the DPT vaccine, Oral Polio vaccine, and Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.

Open vial policy applies to DPT, TT, Hepatitis B, Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV), Liquid Pentavalent, PCV, and injectable IPV.
It does not apply to Measles/MR, BCG, or Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccines.

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one immunization session for up to four weeks provided

  • The expiry date has not passed.
  • Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature range both during transportation & storage at cold chain points.
  • The vaccine vial septum has not been submerged in water or contaminated in any way.
  • An aseptic technique has been used to withdraw all doses.
  • The vaccine vial monitor (VVM), has not reached the discard point.

Ensure all open vials have recorded the date and time of opening. All vials (open or unopened) should be transported in a zipper bag in the vaccine carrier and recorded in the stock register. Well-sealed conditioned ice packs should be used in vaccine carriers and water should not be allowed to accumulate where vaccine vials and diluents are stored.

questions.text: A baby is brought to the pediatrician for the general assessment. During the examination, it is observed that the baby can stand holding support. On giving a small pebble to the baby, the baby tries to hold it between the index and the thumb finger. She also waves bye-bye and can say mama. Which of the following vaccines can be given to this baby if the development is appropriate for her age and if she has not missed any prior immunization?

choices.text: Measles and Rubella-1, Japanese encephalitis vaccine, Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine booster, Vitamin A 1 lakh IU
Measles and Rubella-1, Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine booster, Vitmain A 2 Lakhs IU

questions.solution:
According to the developmental assessment, the child has attained 9 months of age.

A 9-month-old baby can stand with support; has a pincer grasp; waves bye-bye; and can say bisyllabic words like mama, baba, dada. 

Vaccines given at this age:

  • Measles and rubella vaccine (MR-1) -1st dose of measles and rubella
  • Japanese encephalitis vaccine(JE-1):1st dose(In endemic districts)
  • Vitamin A- 1st dose with 1 lakh IU
  • Children who are staying in Bihar, Himachal Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, and Haryana should be additionally given a booster dose of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV).

Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and Japanese encephalitis vaccine are given only in the endemic areas.

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman comes to you in her first trimester and asks for your advice regarding immunisation. Which of the following vaccines would you tell is contraindicated for her?
questions.solution:
Varicella vaccine is contraindicated for her as she is pregnant.

Varicella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine which is recommended for children aged 12-18 months and those without a history of chickenpox infection in the past. It is administered subcutaneously in one or two-dose schedules. 

It is contraindicated in pregnant, immunocompromised individuals and those who are allergic to neomycin. However, patients with clinically stable HIV on HAART (highly active anti-retroviral therapy) can be considered for vaccination if CD4+ cells >15%. Avoidance of salicylates is recommended 6 weeks after the vaccination to prevent Reye's syndrome. 

Maternal varicella infection may result in fetal loss and birth defects. If maternal varicella infection occurs within 5 days of delivery, the baby should receive VZIG (varicella-zoster immunoglobulin) due to the risk of disseminated infection.

Other options: 

Options A: Hepatitis A vaccine can be administered as pre-exposure or post-exposure prophylaxis in high-risk pregnant individuals in a two-dose schedule given intramuscularly one month apart.

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine can be administered as pre-exposure or post-exposure prophylaxis in high-risk pregnant individuals. It is given intramuscularly in three doses at 0, 1, and 6 months. 

Option C: Tetanus toxoid is routinely administered in pregnant women. The first dose is given at 16-20 weeks while the second dose is at 20-24 weeks ideally maintaining a one-month interval between the two doses.

questions.text: Where is the DPT vaccine stored in an ice-lined refrigerator(ILR)?

choices.text: Stored in the lower zone as it is freeze sensitive
Stored in the upper zone as it is freeze sensitive
Stored in the upper zone as it is heat sensitive
Stored in the lower zone as it is heat sensitive

questions.solution:
DPT vaccine is freeze sensitive and hence stored in the upper zone of an ice-lined refrigerator(ILR).

Freeze sensitive vaccines

  • Cholera
  • DTaP-hepatitis B-Hib-IPV (hexavalent)
  • DIwP or DTwP-hepatitis B-Hib (pentavalent) Hepatitis B (Hep B)
  • Hib (liquid)
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV)
  • Inactivated poliovirus (IPV)
  • Influenza
  • Pneumococcal
  • Tetanus, DT, Td
  • Rotavirus (liquid and freeze-dried)

Ice-lined refrigerators (ILRs) are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centers (PHCs).ILRs are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 degree Celsius for storage of vaccines. They have different temperature zones for different vaccines and they are stored accordingly in the baskets that are provided in most ILRs.The ILRs are lined ice packs or tubes. Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ILR. The below image shows an Ice-lined Refrigerator (ILR).

  • Walk in freezer (WIF)

questions.text: What is the schedule for pre-exposure prophylaxis in rabies vaccination?
questions.solution:
Pre-exposure prophylaxis is given on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28.

Pre-exposure prophylaxis can be administered via the intramuscular route with a dose of 1ml or 0.5 ml, depending on the vaccine type, or intradermal route of 0.1 ml volume per site (one site each day) given on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. 

PrEP is recommended for anyone who is at continual, frequent, or increased risk of exposure to the rabies virus either as a result of their residence or occupation laboratory workers dealing with the rabies virus and other lyssa viruses, veterinarians, and animal handlers). For people who are potentially at risk of laboratory exposure to high concentrations of live rabies virus, antibody testing should be done every 6 months. Those professionals who are not at continual risk of exposure through their activities, such as certain categories of veterinarians and animal health officers, should have serological monitoring every 2 years. The booster would be recommended only if rabies virus-neutralizing antibody titers fall to <0.5 IU/ml.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text:
A woman brought her 14-month-old child to the PHC for routine immunization. The child was born in February 2020 at home and has not received any vaccine till now due to the lockdown. The mother is apprehensive about her child's health and wants to immunize him. Which of the following vaccines can be given to the child now?
  1. OPV
  2. Measles
  3. BCG
  4. Vitamin A
  5. Pentavalent
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 4.

In the case of an unimmunized 14-month-old child, OPV, measles, and vitamin A vaccines can be given.

Catch-up vaccination involves the administration of vaccines in children who have not been immunized at all (left-outs) or for children who took vaccines but could not complete the course (dropouts).

According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG can only be given up to 1 year of age. 

OPV can be given till 5 years of age.

Measles can be given till 5 years of age.

DPT can be given until 7 years of age (with booster doses).

Only the above-mentioned vaccines have upper age limits. 

For pentavalent, IPV, PCV, and rotavirus vaccines, if at least one dose is given before one year of age, then remaining doses can be administered and the schedule must be completed irrespective of the age of the child. If the first dose is not administered before one year of age, then these vaccines cannot be administered to the child under UIP.

questions.text:
You should recommend only 1 booster Td dose to a pregnant woman if pregnancy occurs within _____ years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.
(Choose the best possible option)
questions.solution:
You should recommend only 1 booster Td dose to a pregnant woman if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of the TT vaccine with the Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5 mL is administered via the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

For pregnant women :

  • Td-1: early in pregnancy
  • Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1
  • Td (Booster): if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

questions.text:

1. Yellow fever     A) 14-14-2 strain
2. Rubella   B) 17D strain
3. Chicken Pox  C) RA 27/3 strain

questions.text: A child presents at 6 weeks of age for vaccination and the clinician decides to give a combination vaccine of diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus toxoid. How does this affect the body's immune response against tetanus toxoid compared to if it was given alone?

choices.text: Remains the same whether given alone or in combination as DTP
Decreases as the immune system is divided to make antibodies against 3 antigens instead of one
Increases as multiple antigens increases the immune response

questions.solution:
The immune response against the tetanus toxoid increases if given as a combination of DTP when compared to given singly.

Since this vaccine is given for the first time, the response to tetanus toxoid would be enhanced. If it was given to an older child with a history of other vaccinations, immune response would differ.

The immune response is variable in response to multiple antigens depending on the antigenic competition.

  • If 2 bacterial vaccines (say cholera and typhoid) are given, antibodies are produced as if they are given separately.
  • If 2 toxoids (say tetanus and diphtheria) are given with one in excess, the antibody response to the other is diminished
  • If a toxoid is given with a bacterial vaccine (say DTP vaccine), the antibody response to the toxoid is potentiated
  • If a toxoid is administered earlier (say diphtheria toxoid), and then later given as a triple vaccine (DTP), the antibody response to the pertussis and tetanus antigens will be diminished.

Other factors may also play a role in antibody response:

  • Size and number of doses - a minimum critical dose is required, to elicit a response against an antigen. It increases with an increase in dose, up to a certain point, after which it rather induces tolerance.
  • Route of administration- parenteral route induces a better antibody response compared to the oral or nasal route.

*Give Td-2 or booster doses before 36 weeks of pregnancy. However, give these even if more than 36 weeks have passed. Give Td to a woman in labor, if she has not previously received Td.

**JE vaccine is introduced in select endemic districts after the campaigns. Intramuscular (killed inactivated) vaccine is gradually replacing the live attenuated vaccine. This change is because the killed vaccines are more effective and require fewer doses.

***The 2nd to 9th doses of vitamin A can be administered to children 1–5 years old during biannual rounds, in collaboration with ICDS.
